block.para: A function L\from \RNr[n]\to \RNr[m] is linear if it satisfies the two properties below

li.para: L(t\cdot \Vect{x}) = t\cdot L(\Vect{x}) for all t\in \RNr, and \Vect{x}\in \RNr[n].

block.para: Thus L transforms points of \RNr[n] into points of \RNr[m].
The first identity asserts that L transforms the vector sum \Vect{x} + \Vect{y} of \RNr[n] into the vector of \RNr[m] obtained by

li.para: first transforming \Vect{x} so as to obtain L(\Vect{x}),
then transforming \Vect{y} so as to obtain L(\Vect{y}),
finally adding up the transformed vectors L(\Vect{x}) and L(\Vect{y}).

block.para: The second identity implies that L transforms the line of vectors t\cdot \Vect{x} through the origin of \RNr[n] into the line of vectors t\cdot L(\Vect{x}) of \RNr[m].
